The tablet market is shrinking: Apple remains the queen, but there are those who double its share and bypass Samsung (photo)
06 Nov 2019, 17:15 by Roberto Artigiani
The analysis of tablet shipments for the third quarter of the year is clear: the market is continuing to shrink with a quantified drop of around 4% compared to the same period in 2018. In this scenario of consolidation, Apple remains the queen of the sector thanks to a balanced mix of high-level products (iPad Pro) and lower-priced models (the last seventh-generation iPads were launched at the same level at previous ones).
While in Cupertino they are focusing on services as an added value for their devices (see Apple TV +) or on tools that can expand their flexibility (such as support for physical keyboards or the implementation of eSIM on all cellular models), Samsung does not gets similar results with its offer of high-end and media tablets equipped with Android or Windows. From the scenario painted by Strategy Analytics there is a producer that stands out on all: Amazon.
In fact, the online commerce giant has gained strength thanks to a particularly positive Prime Day (July) and a rich and varied ecosystem, so much so as to be able to unseat Samsung and take the second step of the podium. In fact, Jeff Bezos's company has seen its shipments grow by 141% in one year, reaching 14% of the global tablet market.
Difficult though not to read these figures without taking into account the difficulties of Huawei - fourth in the standings - which, due to the ban imposed by the US government, has recorded decidedly negative numbers (-18% of shipments, less than a point and a half of market ). The decline in its appeal in the West has also left space for its rival Lenovo, which has seen its shipments grow by 8% and now represents 6.6% of the sector.
Reasoning instead in terms of the Android operating system continues to be largely predominant even though iOS / iPadOS (so renamed with the release of version 13 last September) has gleaned a couple of points on the market, mainly to the detriment of Windows. We close with a note on the small but symbolically important share occupied by ChromeOS, absent last year, now represents 0.3% of all tablets.
